details.title: Prognostic Degradation Models for Computing and Updating Residual Life Distributions in a Time-Varying Environment
details.standardTitle: Prognostic Degradation Models for Computing and Updating Residual Life Distributions in a Time-Varying Environment

p: Nagi Gebraeel is an Assistant Professor in the Milton H. Stewart School of Industrial and Systems Engineering at Georgia Tech. Prior to joining Georgia Tech in 2007, he was an Assistant Professor in the Mechanical and Industrial Engineering Department at the University of Iowa. He received his MS, and PhD from Purdue University in 1998, and 2003, respectively. His research focuses on improving the accuracy of predicting unexpected failures of engineering systems by leveraging sensor-based data streams. His major research interests are in the areas of degradation modeling, and sensor-based prognostics. He is a member of IIE, and INFORMS Quality, Statistics, and Reliability Society.

authors.affiliation: Milton H. Stewart Sch. of Ind. & Syst. Eng., Georgia Inst. of Technol., Atlanta, GA
authors.name: Nagi Gebraeel

p: Jing Pan is a PhD candidate in the Department of Statistics and Actuarial Science at the University of Iowa. She received her Masters from the University of Iowa in 2007. Some of her research interests include development of statistics-based degradation models.

authors.affiliation: Milton H. Stewart Sch. of Ind. & Syst. Eng., Georgia Inst. of Technol., Atlanta, GA
authors.name: Jing Pan

details.abstract: This paper presents a degradation modeling framework for computing condition-based residual life distributions of partially degraded systems and/or components functioning under time-varying environmental and/or operational conditions. Our approach is to mathematically model degradation-based signals from a population of components using stochastic models that combine three main sources of information: real-time degradation characteristics of component obtained by observing the component's in-situ degradation signal, the degradation characteristics of the component's population, and the real-time status of the environmental conditions under which the component is operating. Prior degradation information is used to estimate the model coefficients. The resulting generalized stochastic degradation model is then used to predict an initial residual life distribution for the component being monitored. In-situ degradation signals, along with real-time information related to the environmental conditions, are then used to update the residual life distributions in real-time. Because these updated distributions capture current health information and the latest environmental conditions, they provide precise lifetime estimates. The performance of the proposed models is evaluated using real world vibration-based degradation signals from a rotating machinery application.

context.text: Most conventional failure models are developed on the premise that the prevailing environmental conditions either do not change in time, or have no effect on deterioration and failure processes [1].

links.abstract: This paper studies maintained systems with nonself-announcing ("hidden") failures that deteriorate due to both shocks and graceful degradation. Shocks occur according to a Poisson process, shock magnitudes are i.d.d. random variables, and between shocks, deterioration occurs at a constant rate. Inspections are performed periodically. Using regenerative arguments, an expression is derived for limiting average availability. This expression provides insight into the effect of system life distributi...

context.text: Some specific examples include [2]–[7].
In [7], deterioration is assumed to be a result of a combination of shocks as well as graceful degradation.

Another crucial difference that distinguishes our work from other prior related work, such as [2]–[7][11], is that we use a Bayesian approach to update the coefficients of the environmental parameters in an effort to enhance the predictability of our model by incorporating in-situ degradation signals.

Random coefficients models, and other models based on the Wiener process, the Gamma process, and Markov/Semi-Markov processes have been used to model degradation processes, [7], [14]–[19], [24], [26], [40].

systems subjected to shocks and graceful degradation
references.text: G. A. Klutke, Y. J. Yang, "The availability of inspected systems subjected to shocks and graceful degradation", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 51, pp. 371-374, 2002.

links.abstract: This paper presents a new methodology for predicting software reliability in the field environment. Our work differs from some existing models that assume a constant failure detection rate for software testing and field operation environments, as this new methodology considers the random environmental effects on software reliability. Assuming that all the random effects of the field environments can be captured by a unit-free environmental factor, eta, which is modeled as a random-distributed va...

context.text: In some cases, random effects of the field environment were captured by unit-free environmental factors [8].

Another crucial difference that distinguishes our work from other prior related work, such as [2]–[8][11], is that we use a Bayesian approach to update the coefficients of the environmental parameters in an effort to enhance the predictability of our model by incorporating in-situ degradation signals.

context.text: The prior work published in [12], [13] assumed that the amplitude (or level) of a degradation signal contains enough information about the component's degradation process to provide accurate residual life estimates.
As will be shown through a real world case study, these developments improve failure predictability when compared to the degradation models developed earlier in [12], [13].

signals: A Bayesian approach

links.abstract: Research on interpreting data communicated by smart sensors and distributed sensor networks, and utilizing these data streams in making critical decisions stands to provide significant advancements across a wide range of application domains such as maintenance management. In this paper, a stochastic degradation modeling framework is developed for computing and continuously updating residual life distributions of partially degraded components. The proposed degradation methodology combines populat...

context.text: The prior work published in [12], [13] assumed that the amplitude (or level) of a degradation signal contains enough information about the component's degradation process to provide accurate residual life estimates.
As will be shown through a real world case study, these developments improve failure predictability when compared to the degradation models developed earlier in [12], [13].
This is similar to the degradation signal developed in [12], [13].
This observation is in line with previous literature related to bearing applications [13], [21], [35], [37].
The second model is a similar exponential degradation model that does not consider changes in the speed conditions (similar to the model presents in [12], [13]).

context.text: Random coefficients models, and other models based on the Wiener process, the Gamma process, and Markov/Semi-Markov processes have been used to model degradation processes, [7], [14]–[15][19], [24], [26], [40].
One of the seminal papers by Lu & Meeker [15] developed a two-stage statistical method that uses degradation measures to estimate time-to-failure distributions.
The assumption of an iid error term has been previously used by Lu & Meeker [15], Gebraeel et al. [12], Robinson & Crowder [22], and Yang & Yang [23].

links.abstract: Design of experiments is a useful tool for improving the quality & reliability of products. This article develops an integrated methodology for quality & reliability improvement when degradation data are available as the response in the experiments. The noise factors affecting the product are classified into two groups which led to a Brownian motion model for the degradation characteristic. A simple optimization procedure for finding the best control factor setting is developed using an integrat...

context.text: Yang & Jeang [21] used a random coefficients model to study the effect of cutting tool flank wear on surface roughness in metal cutting.
This observation is in line with previous literature related to bearing applications [13], [21], [35], [37].

context.text: Robinson & Crowder [22] modeled fatigue crack growth in components subject to cyclic loading as a nonlinear regression model with random coefficients.
The assumption of an iid error term has been previously used by Lu & Meeker [15], Gebraeel et al. [12], Robinson & Crowder [22], and Yang & Yang [23].

context.text: Yang & Yang [23] developed a random-coefficients-based approach that used the lifetimes of failed devices, plus degradation information from operating devices, to estimate parameters of life distributions.
The assumption of an iid error term has been previously used by Lu & Meeker [15], Gebraeel et al. [12], Robinson & Crowder [22], and Yang & Yang [23].

context.text: Doksum & Hoyland [25] modeled degradation at different levels of accelerated testing conditions using a Weiner process.

In the very few exceptions where environmental effects were considered, they were addressed from an accelerated degradation testing perspective, and were only used to estimate lifetime distributions at different stress levels [25].

links.abstract: Many products & systems age, wear, or degrade over time before they fail or break down. Thus, in many engineering reliability experiments, measures of degradation or wear toward failure can often be observed over a period of time before failure occurs. Because the degradation values provide additional information beyond that provided by the failure observations, both sets of observations need to be considered when doing inference on the statistical parameters of the product or system lifetime di...

context.text: One of the drawbacks of the Wiener process is that a degradation measure can take on a negative value relative to the preceding degradation measurement [30].
The Gamma process provides a strictly increasing stochastic function, which is very appropriate for modeling cumulative damage levels [30].

context.text: In fact, the form of the residual life distributions is very similar to the Bernstein distribution [34].
As mentioned earlier, the form of the residual life distribution is very similar to that of the Bernstein distribution, thus it is not possible to compute moments for this distribution [34].

context.text: These cracks propagate to the surface, and dislodge a piece of the raceway material resulting in surface spalls [35].
Bearing defective frequencies can be computed using mechanistic expressions that relate the bearing geometry, rotational speed, and number of rolling elements [35].
The vibration amplitude of the bearing-specific defective frequencies is generally correlated with the severity of the bearing's degradation [35].
This observation is in line with previous literature related to bearing applications [13], [21], [35], [37].

links.abstract: We consider a class of degradation processes that can consist of distinct phases of behavior. In particular, the degradation rates could possibly increase or decrease in a non-smooth manner at some point in time when the underlying degradation process changes phase. To model the degradation path of a given device, we use an independent-increments stochastic process with a single unobserved change-point. Furthermore, we assume that the change- point varies randomly from device-to-device. The like...

context.text: Ng [38] studied a class of degradation processes that can consist of distinct phases of behavior where the rate of degradation increases or decreases as the process transitions from one phase to the other.

links.abstract: Using degradation measurements is becoming more important in reliability studies because fewer failures are observed during short experiment times. Most of the literature discusses continuous degradation processes such as Wiener, gamma, linear, and nonlinear random effect processes. However, some types of degradation processes do not occur in a continuous pattern. Discrete degradations have been found in many practical problems, such as leakage current of thin gate oxides in nano-technology, cra...

context.text: Random coefficients models, and other models based on the Wiener process, the Gamma process, and Markov/Semi-Markov processes have been used to model degradation processes, [7], [14]–[19], [24], [26], [40].

Although most of the literature discusses continuous degradation processes such as Wiener, gamma, linear, and nonlinear random effect processes [40], some types of degradation processes do not occur in a continuous pattern.
Hsieh & Jeng [40] estimated reliability using discrete degradation models based on a non-homogeneous Weibull compound Poisson model with accelerated stress variables.

references.title:
Accelerated discrete degradation
models for leakage current of ultra-thin gate oxides
references.text: M. H. Hsieh, S. L. Jeng, "Accelerated discrete degradation models for leakage current of ultra-thin gate oxides", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 56, no. 3, pp. 369-380, 2007.
